data.title: Working Tree view does not update when staging selected ranges.
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.16.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Modify a file.
2. Open the Working Tree view of the file to see the diff.
3. Highlight changes.
4. Select the "Stage Selected Ranges".

The selected ranges are added to the Git Index, but the Working Tree view is not updated to remove the staged changes (it used to do this).

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: On redhat Linux key map is incorrect (backspace -> [EQUAL], left ctrl -> ctrl-enter, etc)
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version:
- OS Version:

Version 1.16.0
Commit 787b31c0474e6165390b5a5989c9619e3e16f953
Date 2017-09-06T16:19:37.192Z
Shell 1.7.3
Renderer 58.0.3029.110
Node 7.9.0
Architecture x64

$ lsb_release -a
LSB Version:    :core-4.1-amd64:core-4.1-noarch
Distributor ID: RedHatEnterpriseServer
Description:    Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server release 7.4 (Maipo)
Release:        7.4
Codename:       Maipo

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Backspace and many other keys do not work
2. On keyboard shortcut, add a new shortcut to empty map
3. In the key press screen, backspace results in [EQUAL], left ctrl results in ctrl-enter, etc

Tested wit xev, and both key codes are correctly sent.
Works in embedded terminal, only broken in editor.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Code does not support git submodules
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.1 (41abd21afdf7424c89319ee7cb0445cc6f376959, 2017-08-16T18:07:25.676Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
vscode-jasmine-es5|dee|1.0.1
gitlens|eam|4.3.2
tslint|eg2|0.17.0
code-runner|for|0.6.28
Angular2|joh|2.4.0
typescript-hero|rbb|1.3.0
html-css-class-completion|Zig|1.8.0



---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a git repo with a submodule
2. Open this git repo in Code
3. Add a change in the submodule and commit this change
4. Make sure you checkout this commit (of the submodule) in the parent repo
5. The parent repo should now contain a unstaged change with the new pointer to the new commit of the submodule
6. When you open this change in Code, a error message is shown in a popup notification

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No

data.title: Navigate back after cross-file goto-definition takes me to a new location
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.17.0-insider (38853832f83c75a76412d3586dfb8bdeb97a8777, 2017-09-14T07:58:39.362Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063
- Extensions: none
---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open the vscode repo.
2. Go to `ipc.electron-main.ts`
3. Click on `WebContents` in `Electron.WebContents` (line 12).
4. Go -> Go to definition (takes you to the definition of `class WebContents` in `electron.d.ts`).
5. Go -> Back

Expected: Get taken back to `ipc.electron-main.ts`.
Actual: Get taken to a random location in the middle of `electron.d.ts`.

data.title: Long delay when bringing up the build tasks menu or launching a task, when used with an extremely large folder
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.17.0-insider (38853832f83c75a76412d3586dfb8bdeb97a8777, 2017-09-14T07:58:39.362Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 6.1.7601
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
vscode-nuget-package-manager|jmr|1.1.4
cpptools|ms-|0.12.4
csharp|ms-|1.12.1
mono-debug|ms-|0.15.7
perforce|sle|2.1.1



---

Whilst working on VSCode support for Unreal Engine, I have noticed a significant stall when attempting to open the "run build task" dropdown, or when launching a build tasks and waiting for the task to actually start. This appears to be unrelated to the contents, or even the existence, of the tasks.json, or anything else in the .vscode directory. The issue reproduces even when I delete the entire .vscode directory.

I suspect this isn't something specific to the Unreal Engine folder, rather just when the folder is very big, containing a significant volume of data. For reference, my current Unreal Engine workspace is 853GB big, and contains 1.3 million files and around 104k folders. I have configured my workspace settings file to exclude huge amounts of this data, but it makes no difference.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Download the UE4 source distrubution from GitHub
2. Open VSCode, pointing at the root folder 
3. Use Ctrl-Shift-B to open the build tasks drop down
4. Observe significant delay with "Fetching build tasks..." displayed in the status bar

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Vertical Scrollbar - Opaque when minimap disabled.

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: Code 1.16.0 (787b31c0474e6165390b5a5989c9619e3e16f953, 2017-09-06T16:27:49.891Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 6.3.9600

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a file with a line long enough to extend under the vertical scroll bar

2. Disable the minimap in settings using -> "editor.minimap.enabled": false

3. See the text through the vertical scrollbar at any point where the drag handle is not positioned (see attached image)

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

Is there any way to make the vertical scroll  bar completely opaque when the minimap is disabled? I've searched all over but can't find any question for this and as a result any answer. I've tried a number of things within the theme file and settings, even attempting some potential 'hidden' settings as some similar questions have had answers stating some of those but have had no joy in sorting.

I find it strangely distracting having the text visible 'underneath' like it is and it's counter to almost all other text program I've used (visual studio, eclipse, netbeans, php storm, xcode, notepad etc etc, even textareas in browsers).

![scrollbar-opaque](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/29503894/30433191-b472a1ae-995b-11e7-9891-6c32f189dafb.PNG)

data.title: // @ts-check complains about screen.orientation and suggest msOrientation
data.body:
```[js] Property 'orientation' does not exist on type 'Screen'. Did you mean 'msOrientation'?```

Though screen.orientation is what Chrome uses

```  mat4.rotateZ(this.rotationMatrix, this.rotationMatrix, toRad(window.screen.orientation.angle || 0));```

data.title: Ctrl + D (delete whitespace) doesn't work properly

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.1 (41abd21afdf7424c89319ee7cb0445cc6f376959, 2017-08-16T17:16:27.618Z)
- OS Version: Linux Mint 18 Cinnamon x64 
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
python|don|0.7.0



---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. In the editor enter the following text: "a bcdefgh xx"

2. Position your cursor just after "a" which means there should be 1 space between the cursor and the letter "b". Like so (the pipe symbol represents the cursor): "a| bcdefgh xx"

3. Now press CTRL+D to delete the whitespace between the cursor and letter "b"

4. Expected behavior: A single space following the cursor is deleted. The resulting string should look like this: "abcdefgh xx"

5. Actual behavior: It deletes the space, and then the entire word following the space. The resulting string looks like this: "a xx"
Definitely not what one wants or expects.




<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Performance regression due to exe-based extension recommendations
data.body:
We have seen a slowdown in startup performance of 1.16 stable/insiders and could trace this to the fact that `product.json` now contains exe-based extension recommendation that are probed using `cp.exec`. 

Do the following:

* checkout `origin/release/1.16` and build vscode yourself
* due a few runs and write down perf numbers (F1 > Startup Performance)
* now download 1.16 stable from our website and use its product.json-file for the self-build verson
* measure again and see a severe performance hit between 500-1000ms
* remove the exeBasedExtensionTips and performance is back to normal

The following things should be changed

* Don't compute extension recommendation on startup as this isn't needed for a blinking cursor. Re-schedule yourself to run a few seconds after your service is getting instantiated
* Don't use `cp.exec` but read the path-variable to check for the existence of a executable. @dbaeumer is the expert and has some code that does exactly that


My hand-written notes of the performance ticks: *App Ready, start window, window ready, code loaded, ...*. You see that the middle column (using the 1.16 product.json) delays things

![img_3526](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1794099/30426538-b7df43f6-994c-11e7-8859-9eae2c851e4c.JPG)

data.title: Allow "empty" as a choice in snippets
data.body:
I have the following snippet:
```json
	"Create Prototype Method": {
		"prefix": "prot",
		"body": [
			"${1:ClassName}.prototype.${2:functionName} = function $1$$2(${3|...args|}) {$0};"
		],
		"description": "Create prototype method"
	},
```

What I would like to achieve is that I can choose between `...args` and *nothing* for `$3`. But whatever I try to signal *empty*, it results in unwanted behavior. So I'm assuming it's not supported right now.

data.title: Improve workspace service
data.body:
Improve workspace service
- Remove legacy workspace object
- Remove references to hasWorkspace, hasFolderWorkspace, hasMultiFolderWorkspace by introducing getWorkbenchState with Empty, Folder, Workspace states
- Check for places using null check on workspace object and adopt it by using the WorkbenchState or Workspace folders
- Rename roots to WorkspaceFolder
